description: From Middle English toom, tom, from Old English tōm (“empty”), from Proto-Germanic *tōmaz (“free, available, empty”), from Proto-Indo-European *doma- (“to tame”), *dema- (“to build”). Cognate with Danish and Swedish tom (“empty, vacant”), Icelandic tómur (“empty”).

adjectives.description: toom (comparative more toom, superlative most toom)

entries.meaning: (rare or dialectal, Northern England, Scotland) Empty; bare.
examples: It seemed to him that his soul had gone from him, and he was as toom as a hazel shell.

entries.meaning: (chiefly Scottish) A piece of waste ground where rubbish is deposited.

verbs.description: toom (third-person singular simple present tooms, present participle tooming, simple past and past participle toomed)

description: From Middle English toom, tome, tom, from Old Norse tóm (“vacant time, leisure”), from Proto-Germanic *tōmą (“vacant time, leisure”). Related to Old Norse tómr (“vacant, empty”).
